segments.text: The dictaphone, one of the tapes wouldn't inject.
So you're talking about they didn't have, um...
They weren't being imprisoned because... Yeah.
work processes, agriculture, producing, bar, so forth, they were then able to provide a surplus and really class it over.
Then it was possible to say, no, we won't kill it, no, we'll turn it into slaves.
They worked for us because no matter what, we live, we get it by working hard to produce some surplus that'll go to us.
But how does that... Thou shalt not kill became the rule.
Instead of killing your foe, you turn them into slaves, and from one country after another, slavery is developed.
And then, however, the slave system reached a point where it became unproductive, or counterproductive is the word, to continue slavery because there were slavery goals
because the slaves were getting organized and fighting in order to gain the freedom.
Furthermore, they found that it was possible to produce more by giving some right to people on the land in certain areas where they could kill on the subject.
However, they had to pay a certain percentage of the sharecropping of what they produced to the landlord.
So what happened was it was slavery .
And then finally, I don't want to spend too much time on it, but I'd have to say the process of first development reached the point where you had the development of capitalist society.
Now, what the Marxists have done, well, of course, we believe that society started with permits, you know, society, but it's going to go up to the US.
will be also a communal society that's no longer permanent.
It will be a communal society where the productive force will reach the point where it is possible for people to live and that there's a system.
Well, I was going to ask, were there any...
So you were influenced by the people that you listened to on street corners and by going...
to the Young Workers League meetings and from, yeah, your labor?
Being a Jew, were you discriminated against?
And also when you worked for Mr. Barlow and they tried to make you work on a Saturday or Sunday, your only day off.
No, but as far as workers being... Yeah.
You and your wife, Lil, were members of the Communist Party when... And you were... Why were you one of the 11 to be...
Why didn't they pick Lil, or why didn't they... Well, they picked the top leaders of the party, so they picked the members of the National Board of...
And I was one of them.
So, um, well, during the, during, during your trial, you talk about, um, to begin with, you were, I don't know if the word's misrepresented,
But the jury wasn't exactly, you complain about the jury?
Which was misquoted in the Times, correct?
Well, the New York Times and other had headlines on it.
You were charged with conspiring to teach.
You were accused for conspiring to teach.
Now, all through the trial, the way in which you testified, you were conspiring to teach.
There was no charge against you at that time at all.
I'll show you something more about the trial.
And then what happened was that the judge said yes.
If you give them 90 more days, then they'll listen to the government.

Now, what's interesting here is that at that point in time, the judge, to say that the judge in our trial had not yet been chosen, I mean, the judge chosen was the very judge that had made that very prejudicial remark.
Part of us were already found as guilty of trying to overthrow the government, let alone trying to do something.
And he became, his name was Harold Martin, he became the judge in our trial.
So obviously, it was tough to get him to answer.
And also, you said that at one point, that when you tried to introduce evidence about the Communist Party's actual programs, that they ruled them out?
Yeah, they said, well, he even said at one point to the judge,
Now, we are not interested in the fact that you may have been good boys on other matters.
That you may have done good things here and there.
What we're interested in is about this conspiracy business.
But there was no conspiracy, and all you could judge us by is what we were doing.
We were helping to organize the unemployed.
We were one of the leading forces in the country that helped bring social security into the American people, that helped to win the right to organize the strike.
We were very active in the building of the customer unions and CIOs.
We were in the forefront of the fight for black freedom, for the rights of black people.
We were against the toll tax in the South, or the ex-religious laws, other things.
It's not that the worse the better, that the worst conditions will become the sooner that the revolution goes.

We believe that the more you involve people and organize and struggle to better their conditions, the better off you are going to be in order to open up their eyes to what the real possibilities were for a different kind of a new country and a different kind of a new world.
to win as much as you can for the people because they could not get it unless they fought.
No one was going to give it to them.
If there were going to be unions, if there could be higher wages, if there could be shorter hours, an eight-hour day, other things they'd have to fight for.

And as they became confident about their own strength and what could be accomplished for their own unity, they would begin to think ahead to a day when it would be possible to bring more radical change.
And that was the relationship between what we were doing at practice and our ultimate goal.
And so they dismissed all of this then, what you were actually doing?
Well, we were able to speak some of it in.
And so, well, so there was... As far as he was concerned, that had nothing to do with what the charge was all about.
So how exactly did they go about attacking you?
How did they go about attacking you then?
or what they, their interpretation of Marxism?
The Communist Manifesto that I mentioned before, Karl Marx's Revives, Capital, Writings of Lenin, all of those classics of Marxism.
Many of them weren't 100 years old, or not going to be 100 years old, or put on trial.
And then they would take out a sentence book here, there, out of context, and read it, and try to get a jury to understand what it was all about.
You wanted to use, as part of your testimony, an article you had written in 1938, Notes on the Defense of American Democracy.
The only point you have to do is show its limitations in the capitalism.
So, had you been able to use certain articles in your testimony, do you think it would have
that didn't occur in any of the trials.
However, in 1957, it began to change in the country.
It didn't change a certain extent.
The party was out of the way.

Then the Supreme Court, in its composition, changed with Earl Warren becoming Supreme Court Justice against Vincent, who did the Supreme Court Justice in our trial, our court, by taking over the Supreme Court.
Well, do you think they asked you about your trips abroad to the civil war in Spain and the USSR also just to make you look worse?
In the eyes of the jury, yeah.
Because somehow I was a kind of poor agent.
And it was against the law for you to go to Spain?
At that time, or afterwards, there was a so-called neutrality act.
And I remember, at that period, they got the Christianity Act, which was what did anyone travel to Spain.
So that situation, I did go to Spain twice.
So then, OK, so then you were all, the case ended with all of you being indicted, correct?
And even, is it Easterman, your lawyer?
And he was given four months in prison for, what was their, what did they use as an excuse for that?
Well, what happened was, when the trial was over, the judge said...
Well, you were asked or told to jump bail.
and therefore it was impossible to know whether the Korean War was going to be two or more wars.
Furthermore, because we didn't know what the FBI was going to do, they had one decision to make.
In fact, in my book I have a chapter called
didn't you think that was insensitive of them knowing that you had a family and well as i say in the book
They say, well, look, I have children and family, therefore I shouldn't.
And I also say quite honestly in the book that I wasn't sure whether it was because I was more fearful of doing that than going in and doing my time.
So yourself, Gus Hall, Robert Thompson, and Henry Winston were asked to go under.
Well, when you did go under, your wife and your children were harassed.
Yes, in fact, I was able to get 20,000 pages of that.
Yes, that's what they claimed it was, or something like that.
Well, did you have any idea how extensive the FBI and how thorough their investigation was at the time?
Or was it only in retrospect in 78 when you got hold of the... Well, it's only in retrospect, because I always knew that they were active.
But interestingly enough, everything that they had done, they could not know the right way to do it.
We eluded them for more than half a year.
Because actually, the only way they were able to find it on their own was if they had a plan for a time to put it on their own.
But they didn't have anything like that.
Yeah, so you stayed with several people in basements.
You stayed with several people, couples.
You were in contact a lot with Henry Winston.
How about before Leavenworth, were you in contact with Gus Hall at all?
So you were submitting political articles under the name John Swift?
You wrote one article, the parasitism of, or parasitism, I'm not sure of the pronunciation.
The parasitism, or the parasitism of U.S. economy?
Yeah, the parasitism, sort of war economy.
I was taking issue with the notion
that Truman had known just at one point that by spending the military, we were producing prosperity for the country, and this was therefore having
Can you hold on one more minute?
I need to turn the tape over.
